BE11:17am

We believe INDV doesn’t have the resources to pay such a fine
given only $600m net cash last year, the requirement to maintain c.$250m for its debt covenants, and the potential to pay DRRD penalties if it loses the ‘305 patent case; hence we believe it would require either a major rights issue or could lead the company to bankruptcy. However, in our view the $3bn could be a headline number and a starting point for any further negotiations given INDV has been in advanced discussions and has already provisioned $438m. We also believe that the DoJ would unlikely wish to be the cause for INDV to cease operations given its major role in treating the opioid crisis in the US. It is also currently unclear if these are potential INDV penalties or if they would be shared with RB. This is still likely to be a drawn out process with a court case and appeals, so likely still several years before any potential penalties are paid if found guilty.

BornCynic @FATDAZ - BE is now out of a job.............
BE11:18am

INDV's press release counters some of the claims made by the DoJ, specifically around misuse and diversion controls and reduced risk of pediatric exposure with the Film. Furthermore, key allegations may be contradicted by the government's own scientific agencies; full details will come out in court. INDV does not expect any material change to its relationship with government providers as a result of these actions by the DoJ.

If found guilty, the DoJ requests Indivior forfeit not less than $3bn in cash, all key businesses (including Indivior Inc. and Indivior plc) and bank accounts of the company. Such a forfeiture would wipe out the viability of Indivior as a going concern. We therefore downgrade our recommendation from Buy to Sell.

SupposeToBeWorking... @BornCynic Most of these schemes were set up in the past and incorrectly valued at the time. It's known what they cost now, but paying this cost could destroy weak firms. That leaves them the option of continuing to gamble and kick the can - which passes credit risk into the pension holders and PPF. This can be a better option for shareholders than actually paying up (limited liability etc).
Upaswellasdown indivior's debt covenant of min $250m cash is unusual and doesn't seem to be in its filed credit agreement in 2014: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1625297/000110465916141208/a16-14310_3ex4d2.htm. Does anyone have any further colour?
BE11:25am

Despite our optimism surrounding the roll-out of Sublocade and Perseris, failure to reach a settlement agreement with the DoJ means, if found guilty, Indivior could not continue to function as a going concern. Given this level of uncertainty, we downgrade our recommendation to Sell. Our revised target price of 10p reflects some optionality in case of a favourable outcome from legal proceedings.
The DoJ claims remain related to Indivior's marketing practices surrounding promotion of Suboxone film. In particular, the DoJ claims Indivior deceived healthcare providers and payers that Suboxone film was safer and less susceptible to diversion and abuse than other similar drugs

JP11:27am

US Department of Justice charges Indivior for practices under RB ownership
Yesterday US Department of Justice (DoJ) indicted Indivior for "fraudulently marketing
prescription opioid". According to the indictment, "Indivior obtained billions of dollars
in revenue from Suboxone Film prescriptions by deceiving health care providers and
health care benefit programs into believing that Suboxone Film was safer, less
divertible, and less abusable than other opioid-addiction treatment drugs. Indivior also
is alleged to have sought to boost profits by using a 'Here to Help' program to connect
opioid-addicted patients to doctors the company knew were prescribing opioids at high
rates and in a clinically unwarranted manner". Indivior said it would contest these
charges, and noted that DoJ's allegations "are almost exclusively based on years-old
events from before Indivior became an independent company in 2014".

11:27 am
JP11:27am

RB is not off the hook – despite spinning off Indivior back in 2014
As a reminder, Indivior (or 'RB Pharmaceuticals', previously) was spun off from RB in
December 2014. In 2018, RB recognised a provision of $400m (2017: $400m) or
£313m (2017: £296m) related to the ongoing investigations by the DoJ on Indivior
(2017 was the first year a provision was recognised - 2016: nil). RB acknowledged in its
2018 AR that "these investigations and related proceedings are continuing and the
Group has been in discussions with the DoJ". RB concluded that it "cannot predict with
any certainty whether we will be able to reach any agreement with the DoJ or other
parties who are involved in any other investigation or related proceedings" while also
noting "the final cost for the Company may be substantially higher than this
provision".

Tom Dalgleish Kiwi, I've seen spinees tank like this when the spinner was very astute. Can name a few
JP11:28am

It's not just the DoJ fines… this might impact the infant formula business
In the Principal Risks – DoJ section of RB's 2018 AR, the company notes "potential
criminal indictment of the Group or employees, with reputational impact, distraction
and potential debarment which could theoretically extend to IFCN business." It is not
yet clear to us why a potential debarment could extend to IFCN. A potential debarment
poses significant downside risk to RB's long-term valuation, in our view.

Big pensions that can break the scheme if the people (presumably the directors) live too long. Investment returns of 9% per annum assumed. Whole thing is a car crash in very, very slow motion. Buttonwood over at the Economist was banging on for years about pensions - well worth a read.

ASOS has provided a detailed analysis of its business and
highlighted areas such a "newness", pricing and engagement that have been weak across the last six months. It has taken action to address these issues and monetize the assets that it has invested in over the last few years. The company is guiding that capex will be £150m in FY20e (Citi £200m), FCF will be positive and the EBIT margins should be restored in the medium term. This may see consensus FCF forecasts increase but PBT forecasts are unlikely to improve until market sees evidence of improved trading.

Retail gross margin for 1H is –60bps as previously indicated. Distribution costs rose +14.8% to 15.4% of sales (Citi +10.9% to 15.1% of sales) and will be lower in 2H 19. Excluding distribution, opex increased +19.2bps to 32.8% of sales (Citi +21.6% to 33.5% of sales). The 1H EBIT margin declined -230bps to 0.3% (Citi 0%).

FATDAZ what on earth is newness pricing
JP11:39am

Interim PBT of £4m came in broadly in line with PHe of £4.5m and consensus expectations of £3.2m. It’s been a tough half for ASOS, with reported profits reflecting the poor execution of Black Friday and subsequent clearance activity. Previously-reported group sales increased by 14%, with GM down 50bps, the latter helped by a surprisingly robust Q2.

JP11:39am

Customer proposition remain strong. Actives are up 16% and frequency is ahead by 4%, albeit the basket is down 2%. The only concerns around customer KPIs reflect company actions last year, which had a more profound impact than anticipated; ASOS dialled back European activity ahead of the Eurohub automation. Combined with softer German and French markets, organic traffic and customer acquisition fell back (H1 active growth slowed from +9% to +2%). ASOS has responded by dialling back up marketing activity, sharpening European prices, more influencer activity and strengthened product ranges, all of which we expect to reverse the slowdown in active growth, specifically in Europe. US-billed sales increased 80% YoY in the early days of the Atlanta warehouse coming on stream, an encouraging start before staff were overwhelmed by the volumes. Atlanta is now operational, with ASOS able to start offering improved delivery, including next day to some territories as we move forward.

11:39 am
JP11:40am

Forecast unchanged, but a different emphasis.BUY. While headline guidance remains unchanged, ASOS is flagging capex of £150m for 2020, below our £200m forecast. This is well within FCF capabilities at a sub-3% EBIT margin. With sales into the US and Europe likely to build over H2 and into 2020, coupled with management focus on sweating the existing asset base harder in the short term, we see the current financial performance as a relative low point; the customer proposition and outlook remain compelling.

A. M. "influencer activity"?

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: In-line sales growth (+14%) was driven by order frequency (+4%) and active
customers (+16%), with average basket still down yoy (-2%). ASP improved from -6%
in Q1 to -1% in Q2 as promotions eased, also reflected in retail gross margin -60bps,
after -160bps in Q1.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: 1) ASOS has given more disclosure on ASOS Design vs 3rd Party: ASOS H1 sales
growth +5%, 3rd Party +18%, 36% ASOS mix. 2) £24m warehouse transition costs in
H1 will fall to c.£12m in H2.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No change to FY19 guidance – c.15% sales growth, c.2% EBIT margin, c.£200m
capex, YE net debt c.£50m. New FY20 capex guidance c.£150m (UBSe £180m).
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Consensus expectations for FY19 do not imply an upgrade to guidance was
expected, so a muted reaction expected here.

Implications — August 2019 consensus PBT unlikely to change — On the back of this statement, we do not expect consensus forecasts to change materially. For the record, we have a £55m August 2019e PBT (EPS 53p, -45.9% yoy). This assumes +16% sales growth and a -151bps decrease in retail gross margin over the full year. Consensus forecast c.£46.5m PBT
 Buy, target price £52 — Derived by applying a 15x EV/OCF multiple to our Aug-21e forecasts. In 2021e we forecast ASOS will be achieving a 7.3% EBITDA margin (+80bps from 2018A), resulting in EBITDA of £280m. On "comparable profitability" which strips out the benefit of share based compensation and capitalisation of intangibles, the implied EV multiple at this target price is c.20x.

RBC has a slightly tricky to read note about the whys and wherefores here.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

First impression
• We now see rail EPS gone, but higher multiple ahead for SGC LN.
• The DfT has announced disqualification of SGC and its partners from
bids for three UK rail contracts, namely East Midlands/EMT (to be run
by Abellio from August 2019), West Coast/WC (with SGC/Virgin likely to
exit in November-2019) and Southeastern/SET - likely to see just a short
new award to Southeastern while the DfT works out what to do here
despite years of delayed decisions.
• Large contingent pension liability risk avoided: The disqualification is
due to an unwillingness of SGC and its partners to take on significant
contingent pension deficit risk in rail on annuity contracts with likely low
margins. The risk is that not fully known payments in a long contract
might eliminate (or worse) any positive NPV from operations.
• It is unclear to us why the DfT has focused on this issue only now - after
(in cases) years of bid process.
• More eggs in the Abellio basket for the DfT: The EMT award to Abellio,
given Abellio's struggles on ScotRail (where it risks early termination),
and Anglia looks perplexing to us. This turn of events suggests to
us that SGC might now be better off removed from a seemingly (to
us) unpredictable DfT contract-award process, away from unknown
contingent liabilities.
• At FirstGroup, how much open-ended pension liability its WC bid
entails is now a question. Chance of short-term EPS and cash flow at
risk of long-term liability would concern us (given its two last bids TPE
and SWR have turned sour).
• For Go-Ahead, a short duration SET award will be seen as very
disappointing given a share price that has seemed to bake in hope for
much more.
• Back of envelope 145-170p ex rail for SGC potentially: FY21E RBCe
11p SGC EPS sees rail (excl Sheffield trams) exited and a 5.8% fully bussupported
DPS yield. SGC LN's 21-year ex rail PER is 13.3x. In the last 5
years, ex UK rail, NEX has averaged 13x.
• RBCe FY21E EPS also assumes a bus profit impact (~£10m) from
franchising risk, so we are lower than consensus. We think overhead
costs will likely reduce with a lower-scale operation, but based on
present FY21E RBCe EPS 13x supports a ~145p share, and BBG cons
12.8p EPS supports 170p.
• Beyond the knee-jerk reaction on lower short-term EPS potential, we
see scope for PER multiple expansion - where worse than the net
outcome is already priced in.

BE11:49am

The Rail business contributes c£50m (c15% of
total) to group EBITDA (including the Virgin JV), with modest margins
(c3%). The group would henceforth be left more vulnerable to structural
demand pressures in UK bus and/or political intervention on the buses side
(e.g. scrutiny of fares). Admittedly though, an early exit of UK rail may
leave Stagecoach less of a ‘Labour Party target’ given the party’s high
profile criticism of UK rail franchises. We have recently seen National
Express exit the UK Rail business entirely (albeit by choice), though
NEXLN is a larger and more geographically diversified group than SGCLN
(NEXLN revenue c£2.5bn vs. SGCLN ex Rail revenue c£1.7bn), which are
clear advantages.

BE11:55am

One fundamental question on services in our minds is “will they incentivize more consumers to become part of the Apple eco-system”. And our short answer is “no”. Indeed, we believe there are many alternatives to those with other providers whether it is in gaming (very crowded space), banking (emergence of online) or video on demand (Netflix and others). What we do believe however is that these services will increase the loyalty and stickiness of the existing installed base, notably in the US and other Anglo-Saxon countries. All in, we remain far more cautious on services than some of the numbers in the street might suggest.

11:58 am
JP11:58am

The problem that Apple faces is that its core hardware market has run out of growth forcing it to look elsewhere.
Services is the obvious place to enter because it is exclusive services that keep users loyal to one ecosystem or another.
Apple’s core differentiation for several years has been its unique position as a distributor of the apps and services of 3rd parties in the most easy, fun to use and easy to discover way.
I have long been of the opinion that it is Google’s inability or unwillingness to bring Android up to iOS’s level of quality that has allowed Apple to continue earning premium hardware margins rather than anything special being done by Apple.
Services are not Apple’s core strength and the only service that it has that is really sticky is iMessage.

JP11:58am

Moving deeper into services is an obvious move but it brings it into conflict with a number of services whose availability is a central pillar of the iOS proposition.
This is why Apple has to tread very delicately.
It needs to have enough exclusivity to maintain its brand and hardware price but not so much that the key 3rd parties that support the iOS proposition are alienated.
This is why I am not a huge fan of Apple’s services strategy.
The hardware business is so large that services will hardly make any difference to the company’s financial performance and yet they risk annoying some of its core partners.
Staying ahead of the Android user experience is the key to the medium term for Apple, even it does mean little or no growth.
Apple’s shares have had a great run already in 2019 and I think that it is time to take some or all of the money off the table.
